name: hydrazinecarboxamide, n-phenyl-
Reason: 1,3-dioxolane has a melting point around 106°C. The basic unit for our comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of n-phenylhydrazinecarboxamide, we have two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. Additionally, the hydrazine group introduces a strong dipole, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +30°C. The carbonyl group introduces a polar carbonyl interaction, contributing approximately +40°C. The methyl group reduces the melting point by approximately -10°C due to the reduced symmetry.
